repnme.cdata!:
Ukraine - First Programmatic, Second
            Programmatic and Financial Sector Adjustment Loan Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Project Performance
            Assessment Report (PPAR) on the First Programmatic, Second
            Programmatic and Financial Sector Adjustment Loan Projects
            in Ukraine. The ratings for the Financial Sector Adjustment
            Loan (FSAL) Project for Ukraine were as follows: outcome was
            satisfactory; risk to the development outcome was negligible
            to low; Bank performance was satisfactory; and Borrower
            performance was also satisfactory. Major lessons from FSAL
            are the importance of a sound legislative and regulatory
            framework in the financial system, and the greater role of
            the country's overall economic performance, as well as
            market forces, than of formal technical assistance, in
            achieving improvements in specific financial institutions.
            In particular:, (i) establishing a sound legislative and
            regulatory framework for the financial sector is a
            necessary, but not sufficient, condition for financial
            sector development; (ii) strengthening the supervisory and
            enforcement capacity of the supervisory agency is essential
            to achieve the benefits of a sound legal and regulatory
            frame; (iii) technical assistance to strengthen poor
            performing institutions has poor results without a strong
            demand-pull, mainly from market forces; and (iv)
            restructuring and improving the performance of state-owned
            financial institutions is a slow and risky proposition in a
            poor governance environment. The ratings for the First and
            Second Programmatic Adjust Loan projects (PAL I and PAL II)
            are as follows: outcome sustainability was satisfactory,
            risk to development outcome was negligible to low, Bank
            performance for PAL I was satisfactory while it was
            moderately satisfactory for PAL II.  Three major categories
            of lessons emerge from this assessment of the PAL program:
            links and complementarity between the PAL program and
            investment lending need reinforcing, politically difficult
            issues are noticeable during the early stages of program
            implementation and when crucial to the success of the
            program should be addressed early and tranching was to fully
            consistent with the PAL program approach (and brought no
            obvious advantages).

abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is
            satisfactory, sustainability likely, and institutional
            development impacts are substantial, resulting from a highly
            satisfactory Bank performance, and satisfactory Borrower
            performance. Several lessons were drawn from this operation:
            a) adjustment lending programs work well when based on the
            government's own priorities, and when the government
            owns the process. This is particularly important if the
            program involves a wide range of activities, and, in
            addition, having a long-term adjustment program consisting
            of three programmatic adjustment lending operations, may
            ensure sustainability against government backtracking,
            giving an opportunity to see the progress and direction of
            the program, and also the flexibility to make modifications,
            to adapt the program to changing circumstances. Furthermore,
            it is important to ensure an adequate technical background
            work, fostering sufficient capacity and understanding of
            issues on the government's side. Given that adjustment
            programs are built upon the government's program, and
            with the government as a counterpart, thus vulnerable to
            changes in government and political instability,
            constituencies for reforms may also need to be rebuilt. A
            cross-cutting, thematic design provides both flexibility,
            and depth for addressing systemic institutional reform,
            which within its framework, and recognizing the stepwise
            nature of reform progress, the approach provides discipline
            because there is a pre-agreed program of needed, and
            complementary reforms which are to be addressed within the
            programmatic package. Finally, the concept of benchmarks, as
            opposed to conditionality, serves two purposes: (a) it takes
            the Bank out of the delicate situation of imposing terms and
            conditions; and, (b) lowers the risk of the project, in the
            sense that the outcomes are already achieved.

5086335.trustfund:
TF029693-PHRD-UKRAINE PSAL PROJECT (BANK-EXECUTED),TF029500-PHRD-UKRAINE PSAL PROJECT (BANK-EXECUTED),TF028396-PREPARATION OF ENVIRONMENTAL
            AUDIT REPORTS OF HEAVY INDUSTRIAL ENTERPRI
5086335.majtheme: Public sector governance,Financial and private sector development,Economic management

abstracts.cdata!:
The Programmatic Adjustment Loan Project
            aims at supporting the medium-term economic development, and
            reform program in Ukraine, to set the basis for sustained
            economic growth, poverty reduction, and improved
            environmental protection. The project will further improve
            fiscal, and financial discipline, by eliminating
            non-transparent budget off-sets, reducing budget arrears,
            and increasing cash collections for energy. A more efficient
            regulatory framework for entry, and operation of enterprises
            will be in place, to improve corporate governance, and,
            up-to-date regulatory functions in critical sectors will be
            introduced. In the medium run, improved property rights will
            form the basis for the revival of economic growth coming
            from private investments, and foreign direct investments. In
            addition, public sector accountability is being strengthened
            through the public administration reforms, while, in the
            medium term, completion of fiscal reforms will remain a
            strong government commitment. And, completion of the pension
            reform, and improved health and education services, will
            help balance social assistance management. The highly
            volatile political, and socioeconomic environment are risks
            not to be underestimated, given the project's aim to
            reduce budget arrears, and streamline public administration.
